1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program - Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Zero Grocery has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP/PSM/CalARP related activities. 



1.1 Zero Grocery, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Zero Grocery has updated/developed their unified RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name             | Process Chemical             | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration      Anhydrous Ammonia              20,000



Our RMP/PSM/CalARP Program promotes overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the P

SM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2.Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP/PSM/CalARP Program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Zero Grocery operates a cold storage/distribution center for a variety of food products in Sanger, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(3) Cold Storage Rooms

(1) Hallway

(1) Loading Dock

(2) Production Rooms

(1) Water Chiller



1.2.2 Facility Location



Zero Grocery is located at 1810 Academy Ave. Sanger, CA 93657. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.690350, -119.552927. The facility is located approximately 3 miles south of state highway 180 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by businesses.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Zero Grocery is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Zero Grocery has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Process



The refrigerated areas are either equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation or they are supplied from a recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation.



Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room.

1.2.4 Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Zero Grocery consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Zero Grocery is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Zero Grocery has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public i

n the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Zero Grocery facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.

 

1.4 Five Year Accident History



Zero Grocery has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Zero Grocery's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardo

us Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Zero Grocery has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. Nevertheless, Zero Grocery continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. This has improved Zero Grocery's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP/PSM/CalARP related events so that Zero Grocery's management team can ensure that the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program is being implemented.



Zero Grocery has implemented all aspects of the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. When a RMP/PSM/CalARP Program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Zero Grocery has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP/PSM/CalARP Program

implementation.



Zero Grocery considers the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Zero Grocery employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program Zero Grocery will continue to maintain overall plant worker, public, and environmental safety.
